Figure 2. Convergence of several linear models to the Bachelier model for a butterfly option ${ }^{5}$; Parameters: $n=100, \sigma=20 \%, \mu=5 \%, \alpha=1$. Figure (a) displays the pricing functional for the maturity $T=0.5$; figure (b) shows the corresponding Bachelier implied volatilities.

Figure 2 shows the approximation of the same risk-based prices with different linear models having the same volatility $(\sigma=20 \%)$. We compare the following models:

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\text { (Binomial) } & \mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{P}}[f(\zeta)]=\frac{1}{2}(f(\sigma)+f(-\sigma)), \\
\text { (Trinomial) } & \mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{P}}[f(\zeta)]=\frac{1}{3}(f(\sqrt{3 / 2} \sigma)+f(0)+f(-\sqrt{3 / 2} \sigma)), \\
\text { (Uniform) } & \mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{P}}[f(\zeta)]=\frac{1}{2 \sigma \sqrt{3}} \int_{-\sigma \sqrt{3}}^{\sigma \sqrt{3}} f(x) \mathrm{d} x .
\end{array}
$$

While all these models converge to the same Bachelier price, it seems that richer models convergence faster when using the same number of steps in the time discretization. This is particularly evident from the plot of the Bachelier implied volatilities.
4.4. Uncertain binomial model. We consider a one-dimensional binomial model with drift $\mu \in \mathbb{R}$ and volatility uncertainty. Using the parametrization from Example 2.1(ii), we choose $\nu:=\delta_{0}$ and $\Lambda:=\left[\sigma_{0}-u, \sigma_{0}+u\right]$, where $\sigma_{0}>0$ is a reference volatility and $u \in\left[0, \sigma_{0}\right]$ is the level of uncertainty. This yields the sublinear expectation

$$
\mathcal{E}[f(\zeta)]:=\sup _{\sigma \in\left[\sigma_{0}-u, \sigma_{0}+u\right]} \frac{1}{2}(f(\sigma)+f(-\sigma)) \quad \text { for all } f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}
$$

Here, the risk averse agent fears the worst-case and increases the price as it can be seen in Figure 3.

Moreover, condition (3.12) is satisfied for any $u \in\left[0, \sigma_{0}\right)$ in which case Theorem 3.6 implies that the risk-based prices convergence to the $G$-expectation as $\alpha \rightarrow \infty$. 4.5. Bid-ask spread. Using the same arguments as in Section 3, we can additionally define bid pricing operators. Indeed, switching to the buyer position, we obtain that the one-step bid prices $b_{h, X_{t}^{b}}(f)$ have to satisfy the indifference pricing relation

$$
\inf _{\theta \in \Theta} \rho\left[b_{h, X_{t}^{b}}(f)-f\left(X_{t+h}^{\pi}\right)-\theta^{T}\left(X_{t+h}^{\pi}-X_{t}^{\pi}\right)\right]=\inf _{\theta \in \Theta} \rho\left[-\theta^{T}\left(X_{t+h}^{\pi}-X_{t}^{\pi}\right)\right]
$$

Hence, similarly to equation (3.2), we can define the one-step pricing operators

$$
(J(t) f)(x):=b_{t, x}(f)=\hat{\rho}_{t, x}[0]-\hat{\rho}_{t, x}[-f]=-\left(I(t)(-f)\right)(x)
$$

and the corresponding time consistent multi-step pricing operators

$$
b_{k h, x}^{k}:=\left(J(h)^{k} f\right)(x)=-\left(I(h)^{k}(-f)\right)(x)=-a_{k h, x}^{k}(-f)
$$

for all $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}, x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $k \in \mathbb{N}$. Consequently, for every $t \geq 0$ and $h_{n}:=t / n$, the limit

$$
b_{t, x}^{\infty}(f):=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} b_{n h_{n}, x}^{n}(f)=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}-a_{n h_{n}, x}^{n}(-f)=-a_{t, x}^{\infty}(-f)
$$

exists and satisfies $b_{t, x}^{\infty}(f) \leq a_{t, x}^{\infty}(f)$ for all $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ and $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Hence, in the absence of trading constraints, Corollary 3.4 implies that the bid-ask spread for the risk-based prices is smaller than the bid-ask spread for the worst-case prices associated to the $G$-expectation. We now consider again the uncertain binomial model from Subsection 4.4 with reference volatility $\sigma_{0}=20 \%$ and uncertainty level $u=3 \%$.

# 5. Proof of the main results 

In order to prove Theorem 3.2 and Theorem 3.3, we rely on the following results from [18].
Definition 5.1. Let $(I(t))_{t \geq 0}$ be a family of operators $I(t): \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}} \rightarrow \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$. The Lipschitz set $\mathcal{L}_{I}$ consists of all $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ such that there exist $c \geq 0$ and $t_{0}>0$ with

$$
\|I(t) f-f\|_{\infty} \leq c t \quad \text { for all } t \in\left[0, t_{0}\right]
$$

Moreover, for every $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ such that the following limit exists, we define

$$
I^{\prime}(0) f:=\lim _{h \downarrow 0} \frac{I(h) f-f}{h} \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}
$$

Recall that all limits in $\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ are taken w.r.t. the mixed topology.
Assumption 5.2. Let $(I(t))_{t \geq 0}$ be a family of operators $I(t): \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}} \rightarrow \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ satisfying the following conditions:
(i) $I(0)=\mathrm{id}_{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}}$.
(ii) $I(t)$ is convex and monotone with $I(t) 0=0$ for all $t \geq 0$.
(iii) There exists $\omega \geq 0$ with

$$
\|I(t) f-I(t) g\|_{\infty} \leq e^{\omega t}\|f-g\|_{\infty} \quad \text { for all } t \in[0,1] \text { and } f, g \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}
$$

(iv) For every $\varepsilon>0$, there exist $t_{0}>0$ and $\delta>0$ with

$$
I(t)\left(\tau_{x} f\right) \leq \tau_{x} I(t) f+r \varepsilon t
$$

for all $t \in\left[0, t_{0}\right], x \in B_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}(\delta), r \geq 0$ and $f \in \operatorname{Lip}_{\mathrm{b}}(r)$.
(v) The limit $I^{\prime}(0) f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ exists for all $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}$.
(vi) For every $T \geq 0, K \Subset \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\left(f_{k}\right)_{k \in \mathbb{N}} \subset \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ with $f_{k} \downarrow 0$,

$$
\sup _{(t, x) \in[0, T] \times K} \sup _{n \in \mathbb{N}}\left(I\left(\frac{t}{n}\right)^{n} f_{k}\right)(x) \downarrow 0 \quad \text { as } k \rightarrow \infty
$$

(vii) It holds $I(t): \operatorname{Lip}_{\mathrm{b}}(r) \rightarrow \operatorname{Lip}_{\mathrm{b}}\left(e^{\omega t} r\right)$ for all $r, t \geq 0$.

The previous conditions guarantee that [18, Assumption 5.7] is satisfied since condition (vi) is equivalent to [18, Assumption 5.7(vi)], see [18, Lemma C.2]. Hence, the next theorem follows immediately from [18, Theorem 5.4, Theorem 5.9 and Corollary 5.11].

Theorem 5.3. Let $(I(t))_{t \geq 0}$ be a family of operators $I(t): \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}} \rightarrow \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ satisfying Assumption 5.2. Then, there exists a strongly continuous convex monotone semigroup $(S(t))_{t \geq 0}$ on $\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ which is given by

$$
S(t) f:=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} I\left(\frac{t}{n}\right)^{n} f \quad \text { for all } t \geq 0 \text { and } f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}
$$

In addition, the following statements are valid:
(i) It holds $f \in D(A)$ and $A f=I^{\prime}(0) f$ for all $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ such that $I^{\prime}(0) f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ exists. In particular, this is valid for all $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}$.
(ii) It holds $\|S(t) f-S(t) g\|_{\infty} \leq e^{\omega t}\|f-g\|_{\infty}$ for all $t \geq 0$ and $f, g \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$.
(iii) For every $\varepsilon>0, r, T \geq 0$ and $K \Subset \mathbb{R}^{d}$, there exist $K^{\prime} \Subset \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $c \geq 0$ with

$$
\|S(t) f-S(t) g\|_{\infty, K} \leq c\|f-g\|_{\infty, K^{\prime}}+\varepsilon
$$

for all $t \in[0, T]$ and $f, g \in B_{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}}(r)$.
(iv) It holds $\mathcal{L}_{I} \subset \mathcal{L}_{S}$ and $S(t): \mathcal{L}_{S} \rightarrow \mathcal{L}_{S}$ for all $t \geq 0$.
(v) For every $\varepsilon>0$, there exists $\delta>0$ with

$$
S(t)\left(\tau_{x} f\right) \leq \tau_{x} S(t) f+e^{\omega t} r \varepsilon t
$$

for all $r, t \geq 0, f \in \operatorname{Lip}_{\mathrm{b}}(r)$ and $x \in B_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}(\delta)$.
(vi) It holds $S(t): \operatorname{Lip}_{\mathrm{b}}(r) \rightarrow \operatorname{Lip}_{\mathrm{b}}\left(e^{\omega t} r\right)$ for all $r, t \geq 0$.

It follows from [18, Theorem 4.7] that semigroups which have been constructed this way are uniquely determined by their generators evaluated at smooth functions.

Theorem 5.4. Let $(S(t))_{t \geq 0}$ and $(T(t))_{t \geq 0}$ be two strongly continuous convex monotone semigroups on $\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ with generators $A$ and $B$, respectively, which satisfy the conditions (v) and (vi) of Theorem 5.3. Furthermore, we assume that $\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty} \subset D(A) \cap D(B)$ and

$$
A f \leq B f \quad \text { for all } f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}
$$

Then, it holds $S(t) f \leq T(t) f$ for all $t \geq 0$ and $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$.
5.1. Proof of Theorem 3.2. Recall that

$$
\left(I_{R}(t) f\right)(x):=\inf _{\theta \in \Theta_{R}} \rho\left[f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)-\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]-c_{R}(t)
$$

for all $R, t \geq 0, f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ and $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, where $\zeta_{t}:=t \mu+\sqrt{t} \zeta$ and $c_{R}(t):=\inf _{\theta \in \Theta_{R}} \rho\left[-\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]$. In the sequel, we fix $R \geq 0$ and therefore simply write $I(t) f:=I_{R}(t) f, S(t) f:=S_{R}(t) f$, $A f:=A_{R} f, \Theta:=\Theta_{R}$ and $c(t):=c_{R}(t)$.

Proof of Theorem 3.2. In order to apply Theorem 5.3, we have to verify Assumption 5.2. Furthermore, we have to show that

$$
\left(I^{\prime}(0) f\right)(x)=\inf _{\theta \in \Theta} G_{\theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), D f(x)\right)-\inf _{\theta \in \Theta} G_{\theta}(0,0) \quad \text { for all } f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2} \text { and } x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
$$

where $G_{\theta}$ is defined by equation (3.6). First, we verify Assumption 5.2(i)-(iv) and (vii). Condition (i) follows from $\zeta_{0} \equiv 0$. Regarding condition (ii), the monotonicity of $\rho$ yields the monotonicity of $I(t)$ and $I(t) 0=0$ holds by definition. Let $\lambda \in[0,1], f_{1}, f_{2} \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}, x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\varepsilon>0$. Let $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2} \in \Theta$ be $\varepsilon$-optimizers of $\left(I(t) f_{1}\right)(x)$ and $\left(I(t) f_{2}\right)(x)$, respectively, and define $\tilde{f}=\lambda f_{1}+(1-\lambda) f_{2} \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ and $\tilde{\theta}=\lambda \theta_{1}+(1-\lambda) \theta_{2} \in \Theta$. Then, by convexity of $\rho$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
(I(t) \tilde{f})(x) & \leq \rho\left[\tilde{f}\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)+\tilde{\theta}^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]-c(t) \\
& \leq \lambda\left(\rho\left[f_{1}\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)+\theta_{1}^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]-c(t)\right)+(1-\lambda)\left(\rho\left[f_{2}\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)+\theta_{2}^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]-c(t)\right) \\
& =\lambda\left(I(t) f_{1}\right)(x)+(1-\lambda)\left(I(t) f_{2}\right)(x)+\varepsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

Letting $\varepsilon \downarrow 0$ shows that $I(t)$ is convex. For every $t \geq 0, f, g \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}, x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\theta \in \Theta$, the monotonicity and cash invariance of $\rho$ imply

$$
\left(I(t) f\right)(x) \leq \rho\left[f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)+\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]-c(t) \leq \rho\left[g\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)+\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]-c(t)+\|f-g\|_{\infty}
$$

Taking the infimum over $\theta \in \Theta$ and changing the roles of $f$ and $g$ yields

$$
\|I(t) f-I(t) g\|_{\infty} \leq\|f-g\|_{\infty} \quad \text { for all } t \geq 0
$$

which shows that condition (iii) is satisfied with $\omega:=0$. Condition (iv) follows from

$$
I(t)\left(\tau_{x} f\right)=\tau_{x} I(t) f \quad \text { for all } t \geq 0, f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}} \text { and } x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
$$

In order to verify condition (vii) with $\omega:=0$, we observe that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|(I(t) f)(x)-(I(t) f)(y)\right| & =\left|\left(\tau_{x} I(t) f\right)(0)-\left(\tau_{y} I(t) f\right)(0)\right|=\left|\left(I(t) \tau_{x} f\right)(0)-\left(I(t) \tau_{y} f\right)(0)\right| \\
& \leq\left\|\tau_{x} f-\tau_{y} f\right\|_{\infty} \leq r|x-y|
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $r, t \geq 0, f \in \operatorname{Lip}_{\mathrm{b}}(r)$ and $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$.
Second, we show that $\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2} \subset \mathcal{L}_{I}$. Let $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}$. For every $t \in[0,1], x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\theta \in \Theta$, applying Taylor's formula on the function $g(y):=\exp \left(\alpha(f(x+y)-f(x))-\alpha \theta^{T} y\right)$ yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \exp \left(\alpha\left(f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)-f(x)\right)-\alpha \theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right)=1+\alpha(D f(x)-\theta)^{T} \zeta_{t} \\
& \quad+\int_{0}^{1}\left(\alpha^{2}\left|\left(D f\left(x+s \zeta_{t}\right)-\theta\right)^{T} \zeta_{t}\right|^{2}+\alpha \zeta_{t}^{T} D^{2} f\left(x+s \zeta_{t}\right) \zeta_{t}\right) g\left(s \zeta_{t}\right)(1-s) \mathrm{d} s
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows from Assumption 3.1 and Lemma A.2(vi) that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\mathcal{E}\left[\exp \left(\alpha\left(f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)-f(x)\right)-\alpha \theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right)\right]-1\right| \\
& \leq \alpha\left(\|D f\|_{\infty}+R\right)|\mu| t+\frac{\alpha}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\left(\alpha\left(\|D f\|_{\infty}+R\right)^{2}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty}\right)\left|\zeta_{t}\right|^{2} e^{2 \alpha\|f\|_{\infty}+\alpha R\left|\zeta_{t}\right|}\right] \\
& \leq \alpha\left(\|D f\|_{\infty}+R\right)|\mu| t \\
& \quad+\frac{\alpha}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\left(\alpha\left(\|D f\|_{\infty}+R\right)^{2}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty}\right)\left(|\mu|^{2}+2|\mu| \cdot|\zeta|+|\zeta|^{2}\right) e^{\alpha(2\|f\|_{\infty}+R(|\mu|+|\zeta|))}\right] t
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $t \in[0,1], x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\theta \in \Theta$. Hence, there exist $c_{1}, c_{2} \geq 0$ and $t_{0}>$ with

$$
\left.-c_{2} t \leq \log \left(1-c_{1} t\right) \leq \log \left(\mathcal{E}\left[\exp \left(\alpha f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)-\alpha \theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]\right)-f(x) \leq \log \left(1+c_{1} t\right) \leq c_{2} t\right.
$$

for all $t \in\left[0, t_{0}\right], x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\theta \in \Theta$. Dividing by $\alpha>0$, taking the supremum over $\theta \in \Theta$ and applying the previous estimate with $f \equiv 0$ shows that

$$
\left\|I(t) f-f\right\|_{\infty} \leq \sup _{\theta \in \Theta}\left\|\rho\left[f\left(\cdot+\zeta_{t}\right)-\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]-f\right\|_{\infty}+\sup _{\theta \in \Theta}\left[\rho\left[-\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]\right] \leq 2 c_{2} t \quad \text { for all } t \in\left[0, t_{0}\right]
$$

Third, we verify condition (vi). Several sufficient conditions which guarantee that condition (vi) is valid have been systemically explored in [22, Subsection 2.5]. Here, we show that, for every $r \geq 0$, there exists $c \geq 0$ with

$$
\|I(t) f-f\|_{\infty} \leq c\left(\|D f\|_{\infty}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty}\right) t
$$

for all $t \in[0,1]$ and $f \in \mathrm{C}_{0}^{2}$ with $\|f\|_{\infty} \leq r$ and $\|D f\|_{\infty}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$. Let $r \geq 0, t \in[0,1]$ and $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}$ with $\|f\|_{\infty} \leq r$ and $0<\|D f\|_{\infty}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$. For every $\lambda \in(0,1), x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\theta \in \Theta$, applying equation (5.2) with $\frac{1}{\lambda} f$ yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathcal{E}\left[\exp \left(\frac{\alpha\left(f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)-f(x)\right)}{\lambda}-\alpha \theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right)\right] \\
& \leq 1+\alpha\left(\frac{1}{\lambda}\|D f\|_{\infty}+R\right)|\mu| t \\
& \quad+\alpha \mathcal{E}\left[\int_{0}^{1}\left(\frac{\alpha}{\lambda^{2}}\|D f\|_{\infty}^{2}+\frac{\alpha}{\lambda}\|D f\|_{\infty} R+\alpha R^{2}+\frac{1}{\lambda}\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty}\right)\left|\zeta_{t}\right|^{2} g\left(s X_{s}\right)(1-s) \mathrm{d} s\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

We apply Lemma A. 1 with $\lambda:=\|D f\|_{\infty}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty} \in(0,1]$ to obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \rho\left[f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)-f(x)-\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]-\rho\left[-\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right] \leq \lambda \rho\left[\frac{f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)-f(x)}{\lambda}-\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]-\lambda \rho\left[-\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right] \\
& \leq \frac{\lambda}{\alpha} \log \left(1+\alpha(1+R)|\mu| t+\frac{\alpha^{2}\left(1+R+R^{2}\right)+\alpha)}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\left|\zeta_{t}\right|^{2} e^{\alpha\left(2 r+R\left|\zeta_{t}\right|\right)}\right]\right) \\
& \quad+\frac{\lambda}{\alpha} \log \left(1+\alpha R|\mu| t+\frac{\alpha^{2} R^{2}}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\left|\zeta_{t}\right|^{2} e^{\alpha R\left|\zeta_{t}\right|}\right]\right) \\
& \leq \frac{\lambda}{\alpha} \log (1+\alpha(1+R)|\mu| t+\mathcal{E}[Y] t)+\frac{\lambda}{\alpha} \log (1+\alpha R|\mu| t+\mathcal{E}[Z] t)
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\theta \in \Theta$, where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Y:=\frac{1}{2}\left(\alpha^{2}\left(1+R+R^{2}\right)+\alpha\right)\left(|\mu|^{2}+2|\mu| \cdot|\zeta|+\left|\zeta\right|^{2}\right) e^{\alpha(2 r+R(|\mu|+\mid \zeta))} \\
& Z:=\frac{1}{2} \alpha^{2} R^{2}\left(|\mu|^{2}+2|\mu| \cdot|\zeta|+|\zeta|^{2}\right) e^{\alpha R(|\mu|+\mid \zeta))}
\end{aligned}
$$

The lower bound follows similarly and therefore taking the supremum over $\theta \in \Theta$ shows that, for every $r \geq 0$, there exists $c \geq 0$ with

$$
\begin{aligned}
|(I(t) f-f)(x)| & =\left|\inf _{\theta \in \Theta} \rho\left[f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)-\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]-\inf _{\theta \in \Theta} \rho\left[-\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]\right| \\
& \leq \sup _{\theta \in \Theta}\left|\rho\left[f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)-f(x)-\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]-\rho\left[-\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]\right| \leq c\left(\|D f\|_{\infty}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty}\right) t
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $t \in[0,1], f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}$ with $\|f\|_{\infty} \leq r$ and $0<\|D f\|_{\infty}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$ and $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Hence, we can apply [22, Corollary 2.14] with $S_{n}(t) f:=I\left(\frac{t}{n}\right)^{n} f, \mathcal{T}_{n}:=\mathbb{R}_{+}$and $X_{n}:=\mathbb{R}^{d}$ for all $t \geq 0, f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ and $n \in \mathbb{N}$ to obtain that condition (vi) is satisfied ${ }^{6}$.

Fourth, for every $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}$, we show that the limit $I^{\prime}(0) f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ exists and is given by

$$
\left(I^{\prime}(0) f\right)(x)=\inf _{\theta \in \Theta} G_{\theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), D f(x)\right)-\inf _{\theta \in \Theta} G_{\theta}(0,0) \quad \text { for all } x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
$$

where $G_{\theta}(a, b)=\frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\zeta^{T} a \zeta+\alpha\right|(b-\theta)^{T} \zeta|^{2}]+(b-\theta)^{T} \mu$ for all $a \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d}, b \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\theta \in \Theta$. Let $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}$. Equation (5.2), Assumption 3.1 and Lemma A.2(i) and (vi) imply

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{\alpha t} \log \left(\mathcal{E}\left[\exp \left(\alpha\left(f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)-f(x)\right)-\alpha \theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right)\right]\right)-G_{\theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), D f(x)\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{\alpha t} \log \left(1+\alpha(D f(x)-\theta)^{T} \mu t+\mathcal{E}\left[Y_{t}^{\theta, x}\right]\right)-(D f(x)-\theta)^{T} \mu \\
& \quad-\frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\alpha\left|(D f(x)-\theta)^{T} \zeta\right|^{2}+\zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta\right)\right] \\
& =\frac{1}{\alpha t} \mathcal{E}\left[Y_{t}^{\theta, x}\right]-\mathcal{E}\left[Z^{\theta, x}\right]+r_{t}^{\theta, x}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $t>0, x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\theta \in \Theta$, where

$$
\begin{aligned}
Y_{t}^{\theta, x} & :=\int_{0}^{1}\left(\alpha^{2}\left|\left(D f\left(x+s \zeta_{t}\right)-\theta\right)^{T} \zeta_{t}\right|^{2}+\alpha \zeta_{t}^{T} D^{2} f\left(x+s \zeta_{t}\right) \zeta_{t}\right) g^{\theta, x}\left(s \zeta_{t}\right)(1-s) \mathrm{d} s \\
Z^{\theta, x} & :=\frac{1}{2} \alpha\left|(D f(x)-\theta)^{T} \zeta\right|^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta \\
r_{t}^{\theta, x} & :=\frac{1}{\alpha t} \log \left(1+\alpha(D f(x)-\theta)^{T} \mu t+\mathcal{E}\left[Y_{t}^{\theta, x}\right]\right)-\left((D f(x)-\theta)^{T} \mu+\frac{1}{\alpha t} \mathcal{E}\left[Y_{t}^{\theta, x}\right]\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and $g^{\theta, x}: \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}, y \mapsto \exp \left(\alpha(f(x+y)-f(x))-\alpha \theta^{T} y\right)$. For every $t \in(0,1], x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\theta \in \Theta$, we can estimate

$$
\left|\alpha(D f(x)-\theta)^{T} \mu t\right| \leq \alpha\left(\|D f\|_{\infty}+R\right)|\mu| t
$$

and, by defining $c_{f}:=\alpha^{2}\left(\|D f\|_{\infty}+R\right)^{2}+\alpha\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{E}\left[\left|Y_{t}^{\theta, x}\right|\right] & \leq \mathcal{E}\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(\alpha^{2}\left(\|D f\|_{\infty}+R\right)^{2}+\alpha\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty}\right)\left|\zeta_{t}\right|^{2} e^{\alpha(2\|f\|_{\infty}+R\left|\zeta_{t}\right|)}\right] \\
& \leq \mathcal{E}\left[\frac{\alpha}{2} c_{f}\left(|\mu|^{2}+2|\mu| \cdot|\zeta|+\mid \zeta\right]^{2}\right) e^{\alpha(2\|f\|_{\infty}+R(|\mu|+|\zeta|))}\right] t
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\log (1+z)=z+o(|z|)$ for $z \rightarrow 0$, we obtain

$$
\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} \sup _{\theta \in \Theta}\left|r_{t}^{\theta, x}\right| \rightarrow 0 \quad \text { as } t \downarrow 0
$$

It remains to show that, for every $K \Subset \mathbb{R}^{d}$,

$$
\sup _{x \in K} \sup _{\theta \in \Theta}\left|\frac{1}{\alpha t} \mathcal{E}\left[Y_{t}^{\theta, x}\right]-\mathcal{E}\left[Z^{\theta, x}\right]\right| \rightarrow 0 \quad \text { as } t \downarrow 0
$$

For every $t \in(0,1], x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\theta \in \Theta$, Lemma A.2(viii) implies

$$
\left|\frac{1}{\alpha t} \mathcal{E}\left[Y_{t}^{\theta, x}\right]-\mathcal{E}\left[Z^{\theta, x}\right]\right| \leq \mathcal{E}\left[\left|\frac{1}{\alpha t} Y_{t}^{\theta, x}-Z^{\theta, x}\right|\right]
$$

Moreover, for every $\varepsilon>0$, by inequality (5.5) and Assumption 3.1, there exists $c \geq 0$ with

$$
\mathcal{E}\left[\left|\frac{1}{\alpha t} Y_{t}^{\theta, x}-Z^{\theta, x}\right| \mathbb{1}_{\{\mid \zeta \mid>c\}}\right] \leq \varepsilon \quad \text { for all } t \in(0,1], x \in \mathbb{R}^{d} \text { and } \theta \in \Theta
$$

Let $\varepsilon>0$ and choose $c \geq 0$ such that the previous inequality is valid. It follows from

$$
\left|\zeta_{t}\right|^{2}=(t|\mu|^{2}+2 \sqrt{t} \mu^{T} \zeta+|\zeta|^{2}) t
$$

that there exists $C \geq 0$ with

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathcal{E}\left[\left|\frac{1}{\alpha t} Y_{t}^{\theta, x}-Z^{\theta, x}\right| \mathbb{1}_{\{\|\leq c\}\}}\right] \\
& \leq \alpha \mathcal{E}\left[\int_{0}^{1}\left(\left|\left(D f\left(x+s \zeta_{t}\right)-\theta\right)^{T} \zeta\right|^{2}-\left|\left(D f(x)-\theta\right)^{T} \zeta\right|^{2}\right) \mathbb{1}_{\{\zeta \mid \leq c\}}(1-s) \mathrm{d} s\right] \\
& \quad+\mathcal{E}\left[\int_{0}^{1}\left(\left|\zeta^{T} D^{2} f\left(x+s \zeta_{t}\right) \zeta g^{\theta, x}\left(s \zeta_{t}\right)-\zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta\right) \mathbb{1}_{\{\zeta \mid \leq c\}}(1-s) \mathrm{d} s\right]+C \sqrt{t}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $t \in(0,1], x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\theta \in \Theta$. Let $K \Subset \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Since the functions $\left\{g^{\theta, x}: \theta \in \Theta, x \in K\right\}$ are equicontinuous with $g^{\theta, x}(0)=1$ and $\zeta_{t} \mathbb{1}_{\{\|\leq c\}}$ converges uniformly to zero as $t \downarrow 0$, there exists $t_{0} \in(0,1]$ with

$$
\mathcal{E}\left[\left|\frac{1}{\alpha t} Y_{t}^{\theta, x}-Z^{\theta, x}\right| \mathbb{1}_{\{\|\leq c\} \leq}\right] \leq \varepsilon \quad \text { for all } t \in\left(0, t_{0}\right], x \in K \text { and } \theta \in \Theta
$$

Combining the inequalities (5.8) and (5.9) shows that equation (5.7) is valid. Hence, it follows from equation (5.4) that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sup _{x \in K}\left|\frac{1}{t}\left(\inf _{\theta \in \Theta} \rho\left[f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)-\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]-f(x)\right)-\inf _{\theta \in \Theta} G_{\theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), D f(x)\right)\right| \\
& \leq \sup _{x \in K} \sup _{\theta \in \Theta} \frac{1}{\alpha t}\left|\log \left(\mathcal{E}\left[\exp \left(\alpha\left(f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)-f(x)\right)-\alpha \theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right)\right]\right)-G_{\theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), D f(x)\right)\right| \\
& \leq \sup _{x \in K} \sup _{\theta \in \Theta}\left|\frac{1}{\alpha t} \mathcal{E}\left[Y_{t}^{\theta, x}\right]-\mathcal{E}\left[Z^{\theta, x}\right]+r_{t}^{\theta, x}\right| \rightarrow 0 \quad \text { as } t \downarrow 0
\end{aligned}
$$

By additionally applying this result on the constant function $f \equiv 0$, we obtain that the limit $I^{\prime}(0) f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ exists and is given by

$$
\left(I^{\prime}(0) f\right)(x)=\inf _{\theta \in \Theta} G_{\theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), D f(x)\right)-\inf _{\theta \in \Theta} G_{\theta}(0,0) \quad \text { for all } f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2} \text { and } x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
$$

Now, the claim follows from Theorem 5.3 and Theorem 5.4.
5.2. Proof of Theorem 3.3. The proof is based on the stability results for strongly continuous convex monotone semigroups in [22]. The basic idea is that, for a sequence of semigroups satisfying certain stability conditions, convergence of the generators implies convergence of the corresponding semigroups. In many applications, the generators can be determined explicitly for smooth functions and the same applies to their convergence. In contrast, showing the convergence of the semigroups directly is often not feasible.
Proof of Theorem 3.3. In order to apply [22, Theorem 2.3], we have to verify [22, Assumption 2.2]. The conditions (i), (iii) and (iv) follow from Theorem 5.3 and the corresponding estimates in the proof of Theorem 3.2. In order to verify the conditions (ii) and (v), we show that, for every $c \geq 0$, there exist $R \geq 0$ and $t_{0}>0$ with

$$
\inf _{\theta \in \Theta} G_{\theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), D f(x)\right)=\inf _{\theta \in \Theta_{R}} G_{\theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), D f(x)\right)
$$

for all $t \in\left[0, t_{0}\right], f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}$ with $\|D f\|_{\infty}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty} \leq c$ and $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Choose $\delta>0$ such that condition (3.8) is satisfied. For every $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}, x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\theta \in \Theta$, Lemma A.2(vii) implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
G_{\theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), D f(x)\right)= & \frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\alpha\left|\left(D f(x)-\theta\right)^{T} \zeta\right|^{2}+\zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta\right]+\left(D f(x)-\theta\right)^{T} \mu \\
= & \frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\alpha\left|\theta^{T} \zeta\right|^{2}-2 \alpha D f(x)^{T} \zeta \theta^{T} \zeta+\alpha\left|D f(x)^{T} \zeta\right|^{2}+\zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta\right] \\
& +\left(D f(x)-\theta\right)^{T} \mu \\
\geq & \frac{\alpha \delta}{2}|\theta|^{2}-c_{1}|\theta|-c_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $c_{1}:=\alpha\|D f\|_{\infty} \mathcal{E}\left[|\zeta|^{2}\right]+|\mu|$ and $c_{2}:=\frac{1}{2}\left(\alpha\|D f\|_{\infty}^{2}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty}\right) \mathcal{E}\left[|\zeta|^{2}\right]+\|D f\|_{\infty}|\mu|$. This shows that equation (5.10) is valid and condition (v) follows immediately. For $\Theta=\mathbb{R}^{d}$, we observe that, for every $\theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ with $(D f(x)-\theta)^{T} \mu=0$,

$$
G_{\theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), D f(x)\right) \geq \frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta\right]
$$

with equality for $\theta=D f(x)$. Moreover, for every $\theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ with $(D f(x)-\theta)^{T} \mu \neq 0$, one can use condition (3.9) to estimate

$$
G_{\theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), D f(x)\right) \geq \frac{\alpha \delta}{2}|D f(x)-\theta|^{2}-c_{1}|D f(x)-\theta|-c_{2}
$$

for suitable constants $c_{1}, c_{2} \geq 0$. Hence, equation (5.10) is still valid for some $R \geq\|D f\|_{\infty}$. In order to verify condition (iii), we further show that there exists $c \geq 0$ with

$$
\left\|A_{R} f\right\|_{\infty} \leq c\left(\|D f\|_{\infty}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty}\right)
$$

for all $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}$ with $\|D f\|_{\infty}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$. By equation (5.10), there exists $R_{0} \geq 0$ with

$$
\left|\left(A_{R} f\right)(x)\right| \leq \sup _{\theta \in \Theta_{R_{0}}}\left|G_{\theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), D f(x)\right)-G_{\theta}(0,0)\right|
$$

for all $R \geq 0, f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}$ with $\|D f\|_{\infty}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$ and $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. For every $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}$ with $\|D f\|_{\infty}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1, x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\theta \in \Theta_{R_{0}}$, it follows from Lemma A.2(viii) that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|G_{\theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), D f(x)\right)-G_{\theta}(0,0)\right| \\
& =\left|\frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta+\alpha\left|(D f(x)+\theta)^{T} \zeta\right|^{2}\right]+D f(x)^{T} \mu-\frac{\alpha}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\left|\theta^{T} \zeta\right|^{2}\right]\right| \\
& \leq \frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta+\alpha|D f(x)^{T} \zeta|^{2}+2 \alpha|D f(x)| \cdot|\theta| \cdot|\zeta|^{2}\right]+\left|D f(x)^{T} \mu\right| \\
& \leq \frac{1}{2}\left(\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty}+\alpha\left(\|D f\|_{\infty}^{2}+2\|D f\|_{\infty}|\theta|\right)\right) \mathcal{E}\left[|\zeta|^{2}\right]+\|D f\|_{\infty}|\mu| \\
& \leq\left(\frac{1}{2}(1 \vee \alpha)\left(1+2 R_{0}\right) \mathcal{E}\left[|\zeta|^{2}\right]+|\mu|\right)\left(\|D f\|_{\infty}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

This shows that inequality (5.11) is satisfied. Furthermore, it holds

$$
\lim _{h \downarrow 0}\left\|\frac{S_{R}(h) f-f}{h}-A_{R} f\right\|_{\infty}=0 \quad \text { for all } R \geq 0 \text { and } f \in \mathrm{BUC}^{2}
$$

where $\mathrm{BUC}^{2}$ denotes the space of all bounded twice differentiable functions $f: \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that the first and second are bounded and uniformly continuous. Indeed, for every $R \geq 0$ and $f \in \mathrm{BUC}^{2}$, the supremum in inequality (5.9) and therefore in inequality (5.7) can be taken over $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ instead of $x \in K$. We obtain

$$
\lim _{h \downarrow 0}\left\|\frac{I_{R}(h) f-f}{h}-I^{\prime}(0) f\right\|_{\infty}=0
$$

and [20, Theorem 4.3] transfers the previous statement to the semigroup $\left(S_{R}(t)\right)_{t \geq 0}$. It follows from [22, Corollary 2.16] that condition (iii) is satisfied for any sequence $R_{n} \rightarrow \infty^{7}$. The claim now follows from [22, Theorem 2.5] since Theorem 5.4 guarantees that the limit does not depend on the choice of the sequence $R_{n} \rightarrow \infty$.

5.3. Proof of Theorem 3.5. The proof is similar to the one of Theorem 3.2 as soon as we can constrain the trading strategies to a bounded set.

Proof. By condition (3.11), there exists $t_{0}>0$ such that $I(t)$ is well-defined for all $t \in\left[0, t_{0}\right]$. Hence, since we are only interested in the limit behaviour of the iterated operators, we can replace $I(t)$ by $I\left(t_{0}\right)$ for all $t>t_{0}$ without affecting the result. We subsequently show that Assumption 5.2 is satisfied. The conditions (i)-(iv) and (vii) can be verified exactly as in the proof of Theorem 3.2, where we did not use that the set $\Theta=\Theta_{R}$ was bounded. In order to verify condition (v), let $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}$. We show that there exist $R \geq 0$ and $t_{0}>0$ with

$$
\inf _{\theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} \rho\left[f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)-\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]=\inf _{\|\theta\| \leq R} \rho\left[f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)-\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right]
$$

for all $t \in\left[0, t_{0}\right]$ and $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. For every $t \geq 0, x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\theta \in \Theta$, Taylor's formula implies

$$
f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)=f(x)+D f(x)^{T} \zeta_{t}+\int_{0}^{1} \zeta_{t}^{T} D^{2} f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right) \zeta_{t}(1-s) \mathrm{d} s
$$

We choose $\theta=D f(x)$ and apply condition (3.10) to obtain $M \geq 0$ and $t_{1} \in(0,1]$ with

$$
\begin{aligned}
\rho\left[f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)-\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right] & =\frac{1}{\alpha} \log \left(\mathcal{E}\left[\exp \left(\alpha f(x)+\alpha \int_{0}^{1} \zeta_{t}^{T} D^{2} f\left(x+s \zeta_{t}\right) \zeta_{t}(1-s) \mathrm{d} s\right)\right]\right) \\
& \leq f(x)+\frac{1}{\alpha} \log \left(\mathcal{E}\left[\left[e^{2 \alpha\|D^{2} f\|_{\infty}}\left(\|\mu\|^{2} t^{2}+\mid \zeta\right\}^{2} t\right]\right)\right. \\
& =f(x)+2\left(\|\mu\|^{2}+M\right)\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty} t
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $t \in\left[0, t_{1}\right]$ and $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Furthermore, we apply condition (3.11) with

$$
C:=\frac{\left(4\|\mu\|^{2}+2 M\right)\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty}+|\mu|}{\sqrt{2 \alpha}\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty}}
$$

to obtain $R \geq 1$ and $t_{2} \in(0,1]$ with

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \rho\left[f\left(x+\zeta_{t}\right)-\theta^{T} \zeta_{t}\right] \\
& =f(x)+(D f(x)-\theta)^{T} \mu t \\
& \quad+\frac{1}{\alpha} \log \left(\mathcal{E}\left[\exp \left(\alpha \sqrt{t}(D f(x)-\theta)^{T} \zeta+\alpha \int_{0}^{1} \zeta_{t}^{T} D^{2} f\left(x+s \zeta_{t}\right) \zeta_{t}(1-s) \mathrm{d} s\right)\right]\right) \\
& \geq f(x)+(D f(x)-\theta)^{T} \mu t-2|\mu|^{2}\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty} t^{2}+\frac{1}{\alpha} \log \left(\mathcal{E}\left[e^{\sqrt{t} \alpha(D f(x)-\theta)^{T} \zeta-2 t \alpha\|D^{2} f\|_{\infty}\left|\zeta\right|^{2}}\right]\right) \\
& \geq f(x)+(D f(x)-\theta)^{T} \mu t-2|\mu|^{2}\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty} t^{2}+C \sqrt{2 \alpha\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty}}|D f(x)-\theta| t \\
& \geq f(x)+|D f(x)-\theta|\left(C \sqrt{2 \alpha\|D^{2} f\|_{\infty}}-|\mu|\right) t-2|\mu|^{2}\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty} t \\
& \geq f(x)+2\left(|\mu|^{2}+M\right)\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty} t
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $t \in\left[0, t_{2}\right], \theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ with $|D f(x)-\theta| \geq R$ and $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Since $D f$ is bounded, we have therefore verified equation (5.12). Now, one can proceed line by line as in the proof of Theorem 3.2 to show that the limit $I^{\prime}(0) f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ exists and is given by

$$
\left(I^{\prime}(0) f\right)(x)=\inf _{\|\theta\| \leq R} G_{\theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), D f(x)\right)-\inf _{\|\theta\| \leq R} G_{\theta}(0,0) \quad \text { for all } x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
$$

where $R \geq 0$ satisfies equation (5.12). Since the left-hand side does not depend on the particular choice of $R$, we obtain

$$
\left(I^{\prime}(0) f\right)(x)=\inf _{\theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} G_{\theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), D f(x)\right)-\inf _{\theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} G_{\theta}(0,0) \quad \text { for all } x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
$$

Finally, we observe that the choice of $R \geq 0$ and $t_{0}>0$ in equation (5.12) only depends on $\|D f\|_{\infty}$ and $\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty}$. Hence, again line by line as in the proof of Theorem 3.2, one can show that, for every $r \geq 0$, there exist $c \geq 0$ and $t_{0}>0$ with

$$
\|I(t) f-f\|_{\infty} \leq c\left(\|D f\|_{\infty}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty}\right) t
$$

for all $t \in\left[0, t_{0}\right]$ and $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}$ with $\|f\|_{\infty} \leq r$ and $0<\|D f\|_{\infty}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$. It follows from [22, Corollary 2.14] that condition (vi) is satisfied. Theorem 5.3 and Theorem 5.4 yield the claim.
5.4. Proof of Theorem 3.6. This proof of also based on the stability results in [22] and thus very similar to the proof of Theorem 3.3. Recall that, for every $\alpha>0$, we now denote by $\left(S_{\alpha}(t)\right)_{t \geq 0}$ the semigroup from Theorem 3.3 previously denoted by $(S(t))_{t \geq 0}$ and by $A_{\alpha} f$ its generator previously denoted by $A f$.

Proof of Theorem 3.6. In order to apply [22, Theorem 2.3], we have to verify [22, Assumption 2.2]. The conditions (i), (iii) and (iv) follow from Theorem 5.3 and the corresponding estimates in the proof of Theorem 3.2. In order to verify condition (v), we show that, for every $\varepsilon>0$, there exists $\alpha_{0}>0$ with

$$
\left|\inf _{\theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} G_{\alpha, \theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), 0\right)-\frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta\right]\right| \leq \varepsilon
$$

for all $\alpha \geq \alpha_{0}, f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}$ and $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, where

$$
G_{\alpha, \theta}(a, b):=\frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\zeta^{T} a \zeta+\alpha\right|(b-\theta)^{T} \zeta|^{2} \mid+(b-\theta)^{T} \mu
$$

for all $a \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d}$ and $b \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Let $\alpha>0, f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}$ and $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Choosing $\theta=0$ yields

$$
\inf _{\theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} G_{\alpha, \theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), 0\right) \leq \frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta\right]
$$

Furthermore, by condition (3.12) and Lemma A.2(ix), there exists $\delta>0$ with

$$
\begin{aligned}
G_{\alpha, \theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), 0\right) & =\frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta+\alpha\left|\theta^{T} \zeta\right|^{2}\right]-\theta^{T} \mu \\
& \geq \frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta\right]-\frac{1}{2} \alpha \mathcal{E}\left[-\left|\theta^{T} \zeta\right|^{2}\right]-\theta^{T} \mu \\
& \geq \frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta\right]+\frac{1}{2} \alpha \delta|\theta|^{2}-\theta^{T} \mu
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $\theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ with $\theta^{T} \mu \neq 0$. Hence, for $c_{\alpha}:=\frac{2|\mu|}{\alpha \delta}$, we obtain

$$
\inf _{\theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} G_{\alpha, \theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), 0\right)=\inf _{|\theta| \leq c_{\alpha}} G_{\alpha, \theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), 0\right)
$$

and Lemma A.2(viii) implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\inf _{\theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} G_{\theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), 0\right)-\frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta\right]\right| \\
& \leq \sup _{|\theta| \leq c_{\alpha}}\left|\frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta+\alpha\left|\theta^{T} \zeta\right|^{2}\right]-\theta^{T} \mu-\frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta\right]\right| \\
& \leq \sup _{|\theta| \leq c_{\alpha}}\left(\frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\alpha\left|\theta^{T} \zeta\right|^{2}\right]+|\theta||\mu|\right) \leq c_{\alpha}\left(\frac{|\mu|}{\delta} \mathcal{E}\left[|\zeta|^{2}\right]+|\mu|\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows from $c_{\alpha} \rightarrow 0$ as $\alpha \rightarrow \infty$ that inequality (5.13) is valid. Since Corollary 3.4 yields

$$
\left(A_{\alpha} f\right)(x)=\inf _{\theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} G_{\alpha, \theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), 0\right)-\inf _{\theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} G_{\alpha, \theta}(0,0)
$$

and inequality (5.13) can also be applied on the constant function $f \equiv 0$, we obtain

$$
\lim _{\alpha \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta\right]-\left(A_{\alpha} f\right)(x)\right|=0 \quad \text { for all } f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}
$$

This shows that condition (v) is satisfied. It remains to verify condition (ii). For every risk aversion parameter $\alpha>0$ and volume constraint $R \geq 0$, we denote by $\left(S_{\alpha, R}(t)\right)_{t \geq 0}$ the semigroup from Theorem 3.2 corresponding to $\Theta:=\mathbb{R}^{d}$ and by $A_{\alpha, R} f$ its generator. We show that there exists $R_{0} \geq 0$ with

$$
\left\|A_{\alpha, R} f\right\|_{\infty} \leq \frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[|\zeta|^{2}\right] \cdot\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty}
$$

for all $\alpha \geq 1, R \geq R_{0}$ and $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}$ with $\|D f\|_{\infty}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$. It follows from the proof of Theorem 3.3 that there exist $\delta>0$ and $c_{1}, c_{2} \geq 0$ with

$$
G_{\theta}\left(D^{2} f(x), D f(x)\right) \geq \alpha\left(\delta|\theta|^{2}-c_{1}|\theta|-c_{2}\right)
$$

for all $\alpha \geq 1, f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}$ with $\|D f\|_{\infty}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$ and $\theta, x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Hence, there exists $R_{0} \geq 0$ with $A_{\alpha, R} f=A_{\alpha} f$ for all $\alpha \geq 1, R \geq R_{0}$ and $f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2}$ with $\|D f\|_{\infty}+\left\|D^{2} f\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$. Corollary 3.4 and Lemma A.2(viii) now imply that inequality (5.14) is valid. Furthermore, we obtain from [22, Corollary 2.16] that, for every $T \geq 0$ and $\left(f_{n}\right)_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \subset \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ with $f_{n} \downarrow 0$,

$$
\sup _{\alpha \geq 1} \sup _{R \geq R_{0}} \sup _{t \in[0, T]} S_{\alpha, R}(t) f_{n} \downarrow 0
$$

The uniform continuity from above w.r.t. $\alpha \geq 1$ is preserved in the limit $R \rightarrow \infty$, i.e., condition (ii) is satisfied ${ }^{8}$. The first part of the claim follows from [22, Theorem 2.5] since Theorem 5.4 guarantees that the limit does not depend on the choice of the sequence $\alpha_{n} \rightarrow \infty$. Furthermore, as discussed in Subsection 2.2, the family $(T(t))_{t \geq 0}$ is a strongly continuous convex monotone semigroup on $\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}$ with generator

$$
(B f)(x)=\frac{1}{2} \mathcal{E}\left[\zeta^{T} D^{2} f(x) \zeta\right] \quad \text { for all } f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2} \text { and } x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
$$

Hence, the second part of the claim also follows from Theorem 5.4.

# Appendix A. Basic convexity estimates 

Lemma A.1. Let $X$ be a vector space and $\Phi: X \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a convex functional. Then,

$$
\Phi(x)-\Phi(y) \leq \lambda\left(\Phi\left(\frac{x-y}{\lambda}+y\right)-\Phi(y)\right) \quad \text { for all } x, y \in X \text { and } \lambda \in(0,1]
$$

Proof. For every $x, y \in X$ and $\lambda \in(0,1]$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi(x)-\Phi(y) & =\Phi\left(\lambda\left(\frac{x-y}{\lambda}+y\right)+(1-\lambda) y\right)-\Phi(y) \\
& \leq \lambda \Phi\left(\frac{x-y}{\lambda}+y\right)+(1-\lambda) \Phi(y)-\Phi(y) \\
& =\lambda\left(\Phi\left(\frac{x-y}{\lambda}+y\right)-\Phi(y)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The next lemma states some basic properties of convex and sublinear expectations. Convex expectations generalize sublinear expectations by relaxing the conditions (iii) and (iv) in the definition of a sublinear expectation to

$$
\mathcal{E}[\lambda X+(1-\lambda) Y] \leq \lambda \mathcal{E}[X]+(1-\lambda) \mathcal{E}[Y] \quad \text { for all } \lambda \in[0,1] \text { and } X, Y \in \mathcal{H}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{8}$ The result in [22] is only stated for sequences of semigroups but it is actually valid for families $\left(S_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of semigroups $\left(S_{i}(t)\right)_{t \geq 0}$ which are parameterized by an arbitrary index set. Here, we choose $i:=(\alpha, R)$ and $I:=[1, \infty) \times\left[R_{0}, \infty\right)$.

Furthermore, convex expectations correspond to convex risk measures which are defined on losses rather than positions.

Lemma A.2. For a convex expectation space $(\Omega, \mathcal{H}, \mathcal{E})$ the following statements are valid:
(i) $\mathcal{E}[X+c]=\mathcal{E}[X]+c$ for all $X \in \mathcal{H}$ and $c \in \mathbb{R}$.
(ii) $|\mathcal{E}[X]-\mathcal{E}[Y]| \leq\|X-Y\|_{\infty}$ for all bounded $X, Y \in \mathcal{H}$.
(iii) $\mathcal{E}[\lambda X] \leq \lambda \mathcal{E}[X]$ for all $\lambda \in[0,1]$ and $X \in \mathcal{H}$.
(iv) $-\mathcal{E}[-X] \leq \mathcal{E}[X]$ for all $X \in \mathcal{H}$.
(v) $|\mathcal{E}[X]| \leq \mathcal{E}[|X|]$ for all $X \in \mathcal{H}$.
(vi) Let $X \in \mathcal{H}$ with $\mathcal{E}[a X]=0$ for all $a \in \mathbb{R}$. Then, it holds

$$
\mathcal{E}[X+Y]=\mathcal{E}[Y] \quad \text { for all } Y \in \mathcal{H}
$$

Moreover, if $\mathcal{E}$ is sublinear, then the following statements are valid:
(vii) $\mathcal{E}[X]-\mathcal{E}[Y] \leq \mathcal{E}[X-Y]$ for all $X, Y \in \mathcal{H}$.
(viii) $|\mathcal{E}[X]-\mathcal{E}[Y]| \leq \mathcal{E}[|X-Y|]$ for all $X, Y \in \mathcal{H}$.
(ix) $\mathcal{E}[X+Y] \geq \mathcal{E}[X]-\mathcal{E}[-Y]$ for all $X, Y \in \mathcal{H}$.

Proof. The properties (i)-(vi) coincide with [21, Lemma B.2]. Using the sublinearity of $\mathcal{E}$, property (vii) is obtained by rearranging the inequality

$$
\mathcal{E}[X]=\mathcal{E}[X-Y+Y] \leq \mathcal{E}[X-Y]+\mathcal{E}[Y]
$$

Property (viii) follows from property (vii) by changing the roles of $X$ and $Y$. Finally, the sublinearity of $\mathcal{E}$ implies $\mathcal{E}[X] \leq \mathcal{E}[X+Y]+\mathcal{E}[-Y]$ showing that property (ix) is valid.

# Appendix B. Exponential moment estimates 

Lemma B.1. Let $\zeta$ be bounded and write $\mathcal{E}[\cdot]=\sup _{\mathbb{Q} \in \mathcal{Q}} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{Q}}[\cdot]$. Assume that

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left(\theta^{T} \zeta\right)^{2 k-1}\right]=0 \quad \text { for all } \theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d} \text { and } k \in \mathbb{N}
$$

and that there exists $\delta>0$ with $\mathcal{E}\left[\left|\theta^{T} \zeta\right|^{2}\right] \geq \delta|\theta|^{2}$ for all $\theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Then, the conditions (3.10) and (3.11) are satisfied.

Proof. Let $M:=\sup _{\omega \in \Omega}|\zeta(\omega)|^{2}$. Regarding condition (3.10), we observe that

$$
\log \left(\mathcal{E}\left[e^{t|\zeta|^{2}}\right]\right) \leq M t \quad \text { for all } t \geq 0
$$

In order to verify condition (3.11), let $t \geq 0$ and $\theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. For every $\mathbb{Q} \in \mathcal{Q}$, the dominated convergence theorem and Jensen's inequality imply

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{E}\left[e^{\sqrt{t} \theta^{T} \zeta}\right] & \geq \mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{Q}}\left[e^{\sqrt{t} \theta^{T} \zeta}\right]=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \frac{\mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left(\sqrt{t} \theta^{T} \zeta\right)^{k}\right]}{k!}=1+\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{\mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left(\sqrt{t} \theta^{T} \zeta\right)^{2 k}\right]}{(2 k)!} \\
& \geq 1+\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{\mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left(\sqrt{t} \theta^{T} \zeta\right)^{2}\right]^{k}}{(2 k)!}=\cosh \left(\mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left(\sqrt{t} \theta^{T} \zeta\right)^{2}\right]^{1 / 2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since hyperbolic cosine is a continuous function, we can choose a sequence $\left(\mathbb{Q}_{n}\right)_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \subset \mathcal{Q}$ with $\mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{Q}_{n}}\left[\left(\sqrt{t} \theta^{T} \zeta\right)^{2}\right] \rightarrow \mathcal{E}\left[\left(\sqrt{t} \theta^{T} \zeta\right)^{2}\right]$ to obtain

$$
\mathcal{E}\left[e^{\sqrt{t} \theta^{T} \zeta}\right] \geq \cosh \left(\mathcal{E}\left[\left(\sqrt{t}\left(\theta^{T} \zeta\right)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}\right) \geq \cosh (\sqrt{t} \sqrt{\delta}|\theta|)\right.
$$

It remains to show that, for every $C \geq 0$, there exist $t_{0}>0$ and $R \geq 0$ with

$$
\log (\cosh (\sqrt{t} x)) \geq C t x \quad \text { for all } t \in\left[0, t_{0}\right] \text { and } x \geq R
$$

For every $t \geq 0$, we consider the function $\psi_{t}: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}, x \mapsto \log (\cosh (\sqrt{t} x))-C t x$. It holds

$$
\psi_{t}^{\prime}(x)=\sqrt{t} \tanh (\sqrt{t} x)-C t \geq \sqrt{t} \tanh (\sqrt{t} 2 C)-C t \quad \text { for all } x \geq 2 C
$$

Since $\tanh (z)=z+o(z)$ for $z \rightarrow 0$, there exists $t_{1}>0$ with

$$
\psi_{t}^{\prime}(\sqrt{t} x) \geq \frac{\sqrt{t} \sqrt{t} 2 C}{2}-C t=0 \quad \text { for all } t \in\left[0, t_{1}\right] \text { and } x \geq 2 C
$$

In addition, since $\log (\cosh (z))=\frac{z^{2}}{2}+o\left(z^{2}\right)$, there exists $t_{2}>0$ with

$$
\psi_{t}(3 C) \geq \frac{(3 C \sqrt{t})^{2}}{3}-3 C^{2} t=0 \quad \text { for all } t \in\left[0, t_{2}\right]
$$

This shows that inequality (B.2) is valid with $t_{0}:=t_{1} \wedge t_{2}$ and $R:=3 C$. Hence, for every $C \geq 0$, it follows from inequality (B.1) and (B.2) that there exists $t_{0}>0$ and $R \geq 1$ with

$$
\log \left(\mathcal{E}\left[e^{\sqrt{t} \theta^{T} \zeta-t|\zeta|^{2}}\right]\right) \geq \log \left(e^{-M t} \cosh (\sqrt{t} \sqrt{\delta}|\theta|)\right) \geq C|\theta| t
$$

for all $t \in\left[0, t_{0}\right]$ and $|\theta| \geq R$. This shows that condition (3.11) is valid.
Lemma B.2. Let $\Lambda$ be a bounded set of positive semi-definite symmetric $d \times d$ matrices and define

$$
\mathcal{E}[f(\zeta)]:=\sup _{\Sigma \in \Lambda} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}} f(y) \mathcal{N}(0, \Sigma)(\mathrm{d} y) \quad \text { for all } f \in \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{b}}
$$

where $\mathcal{N}(0, \Sigma)$ denotes the normal distribution with mean zero and covariance matrix $\Sigma$. Then, condition (3.10) is satisfied. Furthermore, if there exists $\delta>0$ with

$$
\sup _{\Sigma \in \Lambda} \theta^{T} \Sigma \theta \geq \delta|\theta|^{2} \quad \text { for all } \theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
$$

then condition (3.11) is satisfied as well.
Proof. Denote by $M:=\sup _{\Sigma \in \Lambda} \sup _{|x|=1} x^{T} \Sigma x$ the largest eigenvalue among all covariance matrices and choose $t_{0} \in(0,1 /(2 M))$. In particular, for every $t \in\left[0, t_{0}\right]$ and $\Sigma \in \Lambda$, the matrix $\mathbb{1}-2 t \Sigma$ is invertible and satisfies $\operatorname{det}(\mathbb{1}-2 t \Sigma) \geq(1-2 M t)^{d}$. We obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}} e^{t|x|^{2}} \mathcal{N}(0, \Sigma)(\mathrm{d} x) & =\frac{1}{(2 \pi)^{d / 2}} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}} e^{t|\sigma x|^{2}} e^{-\frac{|x|^{2}}{2}} \mathrm{~d} x \\
& =\frac{\operatorname{det}(\tilde{\Sigma})^{1 / 2}}{(2 \pi)^{d / 2} \operatorname{det}(\tilde{\Sigma})^{1 / 2}} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}} e^{-\frac{x^{T}\left(\tilde{\Sigma}^{-1}\right) x}{2}} \mathrm{~d} x \\
& =\operatorname{det}(\tilde{\Sigma})^{1 / 2} \leq \frac{1}{(1-2 M t)^{d / 2}} \leq e^{M d t}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $t \in\left[0, t_{0}\right]$ and $\Sigma \in \Lambda$, where $\tilde{\Sigma}:=(\mathbb{1}-2 t \Sigma)^{-1}$ and $\sigma \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d}$ is a symmetric matrix with $\sigma^{2}=\Sigma$. This shows that condition (3.10) is valid.

In order to verify condition (3.11), let $\theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\Sigma \in \Lambda$. For every $t \in\left[0, t_{0}\right]$, we use that $\mathbb{1}+2 t \Sigma$ is invertible and $\operatorname{det}(\mathbb{1}+2 t \Sigma) \leq(1+2 M t)^{d}$ to obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{E}\left[e^{\sqrt{t} \theta^{T} \zeta-t|\zeta|^{2}}\right] & \geq \frac{1}{(2 \pi)^{d / 2}} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}} e^{\sqrt{t} \theta^{T} \sigma x-t|\sigma x|^{2}} e^{-\frac{|x|^{2}}{2}} \mathrm{~d} x \\
& =\frac{\operatorname{det}(\tilde{\Sigma})^{1 / 2}}{(2 \pi)^{d / 2} \operatorname{det}(\tilde{\Sigma}))^{1 / 2}} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}} e^{\sqrt{t} \theta^{T} \sigma x} e^{-\frac{1}{2} x^{T} \tilde{\Sigma}^{-1} x} \mathrm{~d} x \\
& =\operatorname{det}\left(\tilde{\Sigma}^{-1}\right)^{-1 / 2} e^{\frac{1}{2} t(\sigma \theta)^{T} \tilde{\Sigma} \sigma \theta} \\
& \geq(1+M t)^{-d / 2} e^{\frac{1}{2} t(\sigma \theta)^{T} \tilde{\Sigma} \sigma \theta} \geq e^{-M d t} e^{\frac{1}{2} t(\sigma \theta)^{T} \tilde{\Sigma} \sigma \theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\tilde{\Sigma}:=(\mathbb{1}+2 t \Sigma)^{-1}$ and $\sigma \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d}$ is a symmetric matrix with $\sigma^{2}=\Sigma$. Moreover,

$$
\sup _{\Sigma \in \Lambda}(\sigma \theta)^{T} \tilde{\Sigma} \sigma \theta \geq \sup _{\Sigma \in \Lambda} \frac{\left|\sigma^{T} \theta\right|^{2}}{1+2 M t}=\sup _{\Sigma \in \Lambda} \frac{\theta^{T} \Sigma \theta}{1+2 M t} \geq \frac{\delta|\theta|^{2}}{1+2 M t_{0}} \quad \text { for all } t \in\left[0, t_{0}\right]
$$

Hence, for every $C \geq 0$, there exists $R \geq 0$ with

$$
\log \left(\mathcal{E}\left[e^{\sqrt{t \theta^{T} \zeta-t|\zeta|^{2}}}\right]\right) \geq \frac{\delta|\theta|^{2} t}{2+4 M t_{0}}-M d t \geq C|\theta| t
$$

for all $t \in\left[0, t_{0}\right]$ and $|\theta| \geq R$. This shows that condition (3.11) is satisfied.

abstract:
We discuss the asymptotic behaviour of risk-based indifference prices of
European contingent claims in discrete-time financial markets under volatility
uncertainty as the number of intermediate trading periods tends to infinity.
The asymptotic risk-based prices form a strongly continuous convex monotone
semigroup which is uniquely determined by its infinitesimal generator and
therefore only depends on the covariance of the random factors but not on the
particular choice of the model. We further compare the risk-based prices with
the worst-case prices given by the $G$-expectation and investigate their
asymptotic behaviour as the risk aversion of the agent tends to infinity. The
theoretical results are illustrated with several examples and numerical
simulations showing, in particular, that the risk-based prices lead to a
significant reduction of the bid-ask spread compared to the worst-case prices.
